Ghliana Cave Natural Monument () is a karst cave located near village Kumistavi, Tsqaltubo Municipality in Imereti region of Georgia, 142 meters above sea level.
Morphology
Ghliana karst cave is carved in limestone and has two entrances. The main entrance has a height of 3.5–4 meters, and width of . The main underground stream flows from this entrance. The second entrance to the left from the main entrance is very steep and measures  from cave floor to the surface.
60 meters from entrance there is a deep siphon lake,  wide,  high above the lake surface and 50 meters long. Behind the lake there is a  siphon corridor with it floor under water with depth of 0.5–2 meters. Behind the corridor there is a gallery with a length of  and a width of . It traverses the bigger  gallery with ceiling covered with stalactites almost it entire length. This gallery again has water and several siphonous exits to the bottom of the cave. The underground flow measures 50–55 litres per second in a flood. The water streams from the cave end up in Kumi river.
Fauna
in the cave.]]
Numerous colonies of bats inhabit the dry corridors of the cave.
The inhabitants of the cave also include Trachysphaera, Attheyella, Pilocamptus, Deuterosminthurus, Proisotoma, Hypoaspis and Macrocheles.
